metadata.case_name: Assignees of Panchu Gopal Srimani v. Respondent

facts.text: Sambhu Charan Das and Sannyashi Charan Das owned 2 bighas and 18 cotthas of land with a construction thereon in Salkiah, District Howrah.

By deed of mortgage by conditional sale dated June 2, 1933, owners mortgaged property to secure Rs. 2,750 advanced by Panchu Gopal Srimani (minor) through guardian Prabhavati Dassi. Provided if not repaid by April 14, 1935, mortgage considered absolute sale, mortgagee entitled to possession.
On June 18, 1934, mortgagors assigned rights to Satchindananda Hazra.

Mortgagors and Hazra failed to repay by due date. Mortgagee filed suit on July 17, 1945 for enforcement, impleading mortgagors and Hazra. Prayed for decree Rs. 5,426/10/6, time for payment, on default annul redemption rights and possession.
Mortgagors' written statement claimed instalments under Bengal Money Lenders Act. Hazra claimed bona fide purchaser without notice, mortgage void as no District Judge sanction for guardian's advance.

Trial Court rejected contentions, passed preliminary decree on December 23, 1946 for Rs. 5,426/10/6 plus costs, payment within 6 months, else liberty for final decree for sale (under O.34 r.4 CPC despite foreclosure suit).
Hazra appealed to Calcutta High Court, contentions: mortgage void no sanction, instalments. High Court dismissed appeal March 22, 1951, confirmed preliminary decree.

While appeal pending, respondent obtained money decree against Hazra, attached mortgaged property, sold June 23, 1950 right/title/interest of Hazra (1 bigha 2 cotthas), respondent auction purchaser, confirmed February 15, 1951. Possession to respondent May 3, 1951.
Mortgagee applied for final decree March 1, 1954, assigned rights to appellants May 31, 1954. Appellants applied for substitution July 1, 1954, ordered January 5, 1955 after notice, no objection.
Trial Court passed final foreclosure decree January 5, 1955, debarring redemption, ordering possession to plaintiff.
Appellants obtained possession April 19, 1955. Respondent learnt May 25, 1955, applied O.21 r.100 for restoration, rejected September 27, 1955.

Respondent filed revision January 3, 1956 against O.21 r.100 dismissal; applied s.151 August 23, 1955 to set aside final decree, dismissed February 14, 1956; appealed final decree Appeal No. 285/1956 without impleading mortgagors/Hazra.

High Court discharged Civil Rule May 12, 1961 in revision; in Appeal 285/1956 set aside final decree noting disconformity with preliminary (sale vs foreclosure), remanded to trial court, liberty to respondent to participate.

legal_issues.text: Whether certificate under Art.133 competent as High Court order was a judgment/decree/final order, despite remand.
Whether trial court competent to pass final foreclosure decree though preliminary was for sale.
Whether respondent, auction purchaser pendente lite of part equity of redemption, had locus standi to challenge final decree and right to redeem.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court certificate competent as its judgment set aside final decree, decided locus standi and right to participate/redeem finally.

Trial court had inherent power under ss.151,152 CPC to correct accidental slip in preliminary decree (form for sale instead of foreclosure), as intended foreclosure per plaint, mortgage nature, no contest.
No intervening third party rights disentitling correction; respondent not ignorant of error, not party, no application to join.
Respondent as pendente lite purchaser bound by lis pendens, no right to redeem post preliminary decree expiry.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Transfer of Property Act s.52, s.91, s.59A

respondent_arguments.text: Certificate incompetent as High Court order mere remand/interlocutory, not final judgment/decree.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sardar Syedna Tahar Saifuddin Saheb v. State of Bombay; Ms. Jethanand Sons v. State of UP

respondent_arguments.text: No power to vary decree to substitute different operative part; cannot correct when represents what court decided.
Intervention of third party rights (respondent's purchase) based on decree, ignorant of mistake, inequitable to correct late.

court_reasoning.text: Certificate competent: High Court decree set aside final decree, decided locus standi and right to participate/redeem finally, not mere remand like cited cases.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court disposed of questions finally, reopened redemption.

court_reasoning.text: Trial court had power under ss.151,152 CPC to correct accidental slip in judgment/preliminary decree (sale phrasing inadvertent), as intent was foreclosure per plaint/tenor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Court's inherent power to correct clerical/accidental errors even post-signature.

court_reasoning.text: No variation of decided matter; slip in phrasing only. Respondent's purchase not based on ignorance of erroneous decree form entitling redemption.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No equities for respondent as not party, no joinder application.

court_reasoning.text: Respondent as pendente lite execution purchaser of part equity steps into Hazra's shoes, bound by lis pendens s.52 TPA; no right to redeem post-decree.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pendency till final decree satisfaction; purchaser bound by result.

holdings.text: Trial court could correct accidental slip under ss.151,152 CPC and pass valid final foreclosure decree.
Auction purchaser pendente lite of equity of redemption has no independent right to redeem; bound by doctrine of lis pendens under s.52 TPA.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sardar Syedna Tahar Saifuddin Saheb v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Certificate incompetent for interlocutory finding not disposing suit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ms. Jethanand Sons v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Remand for fresh trial not final judgment.
Court's inherent power over records to correct mistakes.
Correction of accidental error in decree (mesne vs net profits) under ss.151,152 even post-certificate.
Decree altered contrary to intent gathered from whole judgment.
Correction too late if third party rights intervene based on ignorance of error.
Illustrates lis pendens binding pendente lite purchaser.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Preliminary/final decrees in mortgage suits; correction of errors; inherent powers; execution.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: Right to redeem by those with interest in equity; lis pendens binding pendente lite purchasers.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, held High Court certificate competent, trial court's final foreclosure decree valid after correcting accidental slip in preliminary decree, respondent as pendente lite purchaser had no locus to challenge or redeem.
outcome.relief_granted: Final foreclosure decree upheld; High Court judgment/decree set aside.

key_quotes.text: It is well-settled that there is an inherent power in the court which passed the judgment to correct a clerical mistake or an error arising from an accidental slip or omission.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms power under ss.151,152 CPC to correct decrees.

key_quotes.text: Under section 52 which incorporates the doctrine of lis pendens, during the pendency of a suit... such a property cannot be transferred... so as to affect the rights of any other party thereto under any decree.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains binding effect on pendente lite purchaser.

key_quotes.text: The purchaser pendente lite under this doctrine is bound by the result of the litigation.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Denies independent redemption right to respondent.
